maml:description.maml:para: Trigger backup for a protected item

Using this commandlet is the equivalent of "Backup Now". It triggers an ad-hoc backup that is not tied to the backup schedule. This is useful in two scenarios: 1. Starting initial backup immediately after enabling protection 2. Triggering ad-hoc backup when a previous scheduled backup has failed
The Azure Backup item for which ad-hoc backup is being triggered
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The Azure Backup item for which ad-hoc backup is being triggered
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

maml:alert.maml:para: When an existing backup job is running this commandlet will fail.

dev:remarks.maml:para: WorkloadName Operation Status StartTime EndTime ------------ --------- ------ --------- ------- test-vm Backup InProgress 26-Aug-15 12:24:01 PM 01-Jan-01 12:00:00 AM

maml:description.maml:para: Disable protection for a protected item
To stop regular scheduled backup of a backup item and to delete existing recovery points associated with the backup item.

An optional switch parameter that deletes the recovery points data associated with a backup item. It is possible to disable backup and keep the recovery points data by NOT supplying this parameter. At a later point the same commandlet can be used to delete the data
The Azure Backup item for which protection is being disabled.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object

An optional switch parameter that deletes the recovery points data associated with a backup item. It is possible to disable backup and keep the recovery points data by NOT supplying this parameter. At a later point the same commandlet can be used to delete the data
The Azure Backup item for which protection is being disabled.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.
Allow re-registration of the server to connect the server back to the vault and continue the backup points chain.

When a server is destroyed, all its cloud backup points remain in the Azure Backup vault. If the server is rebuilt and given the same FQDN, it is possible to connect it back to the same vault. This will allow the server to continue taking backups and adding new backup points to the existing set - essentially continuing where it was left off in the backup chain.

To make this connection, the AzureBackupContainer has to be primed for "re-registration". Without this step, you can lose all the existing data as a part of the registration process. The commandlet tells the service that the next time the container is registered, it should continue the backup chain.
An object referencing the container for which re-registration is being requested
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
An object referencing the container for which re-registration is being requested
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
Associate an item with a protection policy

Enabling protection involves two key entities - the AzureRMBackupItem and the AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy. Both need to belong to the same vault. The backup schedule will take care of doing the full initial copy for the item and the incremental copy for the subsequent backups.
The Azure Backup protection policy that will be associated with the item.
The Azure Backup item object for which protection is being enabled.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The Azure Backup protection policy that will be associated with the item.
The Azure Backup item object for which protection is being enabled.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

dev:remarks.maml:para: WorkloadName Operation Status StartTime EndTime ------------ --------- ------ --------- ------- test-vm ConfigureBackup Completed 26-Aug-15 12:19:49 PM 26-Aug-15 12:19:54 PM

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves one or more Azure Backup containers that match the filter criteria specified.

An AzureBackupContainer is an object that encapsulates datasources, protected items, and recovery points. An AzureBackupContainer can be one of three: - a Windows server - a System Center Data Protection Manager server (SCDPM) - an Azure IaaS virtual machine

Before a datasource or item can be backed-up, the container holding it must be registered with the Azure Backup service and be authenticated to send backup data to the backup vault. For Windows and SCDPM servers, the registration is held with the FQDN of the server.
Name of the container to be retrieved.
Type of the container. Currently supported types are Windows
The resource group name associated with the container. When registering the container this input would have been provided using the -ServiceName or the -ResourceGroupName parameter.
The current status of the container object. Supported values are: NotRegistered, Registered, Registering,
The Azure Backup vault from to which the container is associated.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Name of the container to be retrieved.
Type of the container. Currently supported types are Windows
The resource group name associated with the container. When registering the container this input would have been provided using the -ServiceName or the -ResourceGroupName parameter.
The current status of the container object. Supported values are: NotRegistered, Registered, Registering,
The Azure Backup vault from to which the container is associated.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the items under a container

A container registered to the Azure Backup vault can have one or more items that can be protected. These items are enabled for protection using the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet. This commandlet gets all the items under the container and their protection status.
The overall protection status of the item in the container. Supported values are: Protected, Protecting.

The backup status for the item. Supported values are: IRPending, Protected, ProtectionError, ProtectionStopped. This is a sub-status that can be used as a filter for items that have -ProtectionStatus as Protected.
The type of item that is being requested. Supported values: AzureVM
The parent container object for which we are querying the items. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupContainer commandlet to get the list of containers in the vault.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The overall protection status of the item in the container. Supported values are: Protected, Protecting.

The backup status for the item. Supported values are: IRPending, Protected, ProtectionError, ProtectionStopped. This is a sub-status that can be used as a filter for items that have -ProtectionStatus as Protected.
The type of item that is being requested. Supported values: AzureVM
The parent container object for which we are querying the items. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupContainer commandlet to get the list of containers in the vault.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a list of jobs or a specific job
This commandlet gets the Azure Backup jobs that match the filter criteria specified. The jobs returned are restricted to the Azure Backup vault.

The specific Azure Backup vault object for which the jobs are being retrieved. The vault is the parent container for an Azure Backup job, and any given job must be a part of a specified vault. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
The unique identifier for the Azure Backup job.
A time range is specified to filter the list of jobs returned from the Azure Backup service. This parameter specifies the start time for the time range.
When this parameter is not specified, the default is _____
When the -To parameter is used the -From parameter is mandatory.
A time range is specified to filter the list of jobs returned from the Azure Backup service. This parameter specifies the end time for the time range.
When this parameter is not specified, the default vault is the current system date/time.
A filter value to get jobs with the specified status. Typically the status field is used to get InProgress and Failed jobs.
Supported values: - InProgress - Failed - Cancelled - Cancelling - Completed - CompletedWithWarnings
The type of container that is used as a filter. The only supported item currently is AzureVM.
A filter that describes the specific operation for which the jobs will be retrieved.
Supported values: - Backup - ConfigureBackup - DeleteBackupData - Register - Restore - UnProtect - Unregister
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object

When you use the -Job parameter, the commandlet fetches the latest status for the job. Identifying the job is done using the details provided in the input object. This input object would also have been returned earlier from Get-AzureRMBackupJob.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object

The specific Azure Backup vault object for which the jobs are being retrieved. The vault is the parent container for an Azure Backup job, and any given job must be a part of a specified vault. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
The unique identifier for the Azure Backup job.
A time range is specified to filter the list of jobs returned from the Azure Backup service. This parameter specifies the start time for the time range.
When this parameter is not specified, the default is _____
When the -To parameter is used the -From parameter is mandatory.
A time range is specified to filter the list of jobs returned from the Azure Backup service. This parameter specifies the end time for the time range.
When this parameter is not specified, the default vault is the current system date/time.
A filter value to get jobs with the specified status. Typically the status field is used to get InProgress and Failed jobs.
Supported values: - InProgress - Failed - Cancelled - Cancelling - Completed - CompletedWithWarnings
The type of container that is used as a filter. The only supported item currently is AzureVM.
A filter that describes the specific operation for which the jobs will be retrieved.
Supported values: - Backup - ConfigureBackup - DeleteBackupData - Register - Restore - UnProtect - Unregister
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object

When you use the -Job parameter, the commandlet fetches the latest status for the job. Identifying the job is done using the details provided in the input object. This input object would also have been returned earlier from Get-AzureRMBackupJob.
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Fetches the backup policies in a backup vault

The backup policy is used in the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet to enable protection on an item. The policy must be created using the New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet, or an existing policy can be used. This commandlet gets the list of existing policies in the backup vault.
The name of the specific policy. Since policy names are unique within a vault, the name is sufficient to identify a policy.
The Azure Backup vault under which the policy has been created.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The name of the specific policy. Since policy names are unique within a vault, the name is sufficient to identify a policy.
The Azure Backup vault under which the policy has been created.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves one or more vault objects based on the parameters that are specified.

The Get-AzureRMBackupVault commandlet retrieves existing Azure Backup vaults and returns objects of type AzurePSBackupVault. The vault object is used in some Azure Backup commandlets as a mandatory parameter.
The Azure resource group under which the vault was created.

The name of the specific Azure Backup vault that needs to be retrieved. If no name is specified, then the commandlet returns all the vaults created by the subscription. If there is more than 1 backup vault with the same name then the commandlet returns all the vaults that match the name. Use the -ResourceGroupName parameter to filter results and get a unique vault.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The Azure resource group under which the vault was created.

The name of the specific Azure Backup vault that needs to be retrieved. If no name is specified, then the commandlet returns all the vaults created by the subscription. If there is more than 1 backup vault with the same name then the commandlet returns all the vaults that match the name. Use the -ResourceGroupName parameter to filter results and get a unique vault.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

maml:description.maml:para: Downloads the Vault Credentials file to a specified location.

To enable hybrid backup scenarios the Vault Credentials file is a critical component. The vault credential file is used to connect a server to the Azure Backup vault and register it. Only after registration can backup data be sent to the vault. The Get-AzureRMBackupVaultCredentials commandlet downloads and places a vault credential file at the location specified by the user.
The destination path where the Vault Credentials file should be placed.
The specific Azure Backup vault object for which the Vault Credential file is generated. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The destination path where the Vault Credentials file should be placed.
The specific Azure Backup vault object for which the Vault Credential file is generated. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.
Creates a PowerShell object that holds backup policy information

A backup policy defines when and how often the backup of an item is done. This commandlet creates a PowerShell object that holds backup policy information. The backup policy is used as an input to the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet.
There are 4 types of retention - Daily, Weekly, Monthly, and Yearly. You need to create one object for each type of retention that you plan to use.
The name of the backup policy. It should be unique within a vault.
The type of backup item on which the policy can be applied. Currently, the only supported value for is AzureVM.
The time of the day when backup should be triggered.
Specifies one or more days of the week when backup will be triggered at the time specified using the -BackupTime option. This parameter needs to be used with the -Weekly flag.
A list of one or more retention policies that are associated with this backup policy. Use the New-AzureRMBackupRetentionPolicyObject to create retention policies.
The Azure Backup vault that is the parent for the backup policy.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object.
The name of the backup policy. It should be unique within a vault.
The type of backup item on which the policy can be applied. Currently, the only supported value for is AzureVM.
A flag for indicating that the backup policy will be triggered daily.
The time of the day when backup should be triggered.
A list of one or more retention policies that are associated with this backup policy. Use the New-AzureRMBackupRetentionPolicyObject to create retention policies.
The Azure Backup vault that is the parent for the backup policy.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object.
The name of the backup policy. It should be unique within a vault.
The type of backup item on which the policy can be applied. Currently, the only supported value for is AzureVM.
A flag for indicating that the backup policy will be triggered on one more days of the week.
The time of the day when backup should be triggered.
Specifies one or more days of the week when backup will be triggered at the time specified using the -BackupTime option. This parameter needs to be used with the -Weekly flag.
A list of one or more retention policies that are associated with this backup policy. Use the New-AzureRMBackupRetentionPolicyObject to create retention policies.
The Azure Backup vault that is the parent for the backup policy.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object.
The name of the backup policy. It should be unique within a vault.
The type of backup item on which the policy can be applied. Currently, the only supported value for is AzureVM.
The time of the day when backup should be triggered.
Specifies one or more days of the week when backup will be triggered at the time specified using the -BackupTime option. This parameter needs to be used with the -Weekly flag.
A list of one or more retention policies that are associated with this backup policy. Use the New-AzureRMBackupRetentionPolicyObject to create retention policies.
The Azure Backup vault that is the parent for the backup policy.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object.
A flag for indicating that the backup policy will be triggered daily.
A flag for indicating that the backup policy will be triggered on one more days of the week.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a PowerShell object that holds retention policy information

A backup policy is associated with at least one retention policy. The retention policy defines how long a recovery point is kept with Azure Backup. This commandlet creates PowerShell objects that hold retention policy information. These retention policy objects are used as inputs to the New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet, or directly with the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet.
There are 4 types of retention - Daily, Weekly, Monthly, and Yearly. You need to create one object for each type of retention that you plan to use.
Switch parameter that creates an object with Daily retention information.

The retention period for which the backup point will be stored. This unit depends on the switch option specified in the commandlet. For example, if you are using the -DailyRetention flag then this value specifies the retention in days. Or if you are using the -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat flag then this value specifies the retention in months.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Switch parameter that creates an object with Weekly retention information.

The days of the week used to identify which recovery points will be retained and for how long. This parameter works with the -WeeklyRetention, -MonthlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat, and -YearlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat options.

NOTE: You need to ensure that the days of the week that are picked for backup and for retention are aligned! For example, if backup is set for Saturdays then the weekly/monthly/yearly retention policies also must use Saturday as the -DaysOfWeek option.

The retention period for which the backup point will be stored. This unit depends on the switch option specified in the commandlet. For example, if you are using the -DailyRetention flag then this value specifies the retention in days. Or if you are using the -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat flag then this value specifies the retention in months.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Switch parameter that creates an object with Monthly retention information.

The days of the month used to identify which recovery points will be retained and for how long. This parameter works with the -DailyRetention, -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat, and -YearlyRetentionInDailyFormat options.

The retention period for which the backup point will be stored. This unit depends on the switch option specified in the commandlet. For example, if you are using the -DailyRetention flag then this value specifies the retention in days. Or if you are using the -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat flag then this value specifies the retention in months.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Switch parameter that creates an object with Monthly retention information.

The days of the week used to identify which recovery points will be retained and for how long. This parameter works with the -WeeklyRetention, -MonthlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat, and -YearlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat options.

NOTE: You need to ensure that the days of the week that are picked for backup and for retention are aligned! For example, if backup is set for Saturdays then the weekly/monthly/yearly retention policies also must use Saturday as the -DaysOfWeek option.
When defining monthly retention, this parameter specifies which week of the month has the recovery points that should get monthly retention.

The retention period for which the backup point will be stored. This unit depends on the switch option specified in the commandlet. For example, if you are using the -DailyRetention flag then this value specifies the retention in days. Or if you are using the -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat flag then this value specifies the retention in months.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Switch parameter that creates an object with Yearly retention information.

The days of the month used to identify which recovery points will be retained and for how long. This parameter works with the -DailyRetention, -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat, and -YearlyRetentionInDailyFormat options.
When defining yearly retention, this parameter specifies which months of the year has the recovery points that should get yearly retention.

The retention period for which the backup point will be stored. This unit depends on the switch option specified in the commandlet. For example, if you are using the -DailyRetention flag then this value specifies the retention in days. Or if you are using the -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat flag then this value specifies the retention in months.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Switch parameter that creates an object with Yearly retention information.

The days of the week used to identify which recovery points will be retained and for how long. This parameter works with the -WeeklyRetention, -MonthlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat, and -YearlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat options.

NOTE: You need to ensure that the days of the week that are picked for backup and for retention are aligned! For example, if backup is set for Saturdays then the weekly/monthly/yearly retention policies also must use Saturday as the -DaysOfWeek option.
When defining monthly retention, this parameter specifies which week of the month has the recovery points that should get monthly retention.
When defining yearly retention, this parameter specifies which months of the year has the recovery points that should get yearly retention.

The retention period for which the backup point will be stored. This unit depends on the switch option specified in the commandlet. For example, if you are using the -DailyRetention flag then this value specifies the retention in days. Or if you are using the -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat flag then this value specifies the retention in months.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Switch parameter that creates an object with Daily retention information.

The retention period for which the backup point will be stored. This unit depends on the switch option specified in the commandlet. For example, if you are using the -DailyRetention flag then this value specifies the retention in days. Or if you are using the -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat flag then this value specifies the retention in months.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Switch parameter that creates an object with Weekly retention information.

The days of the week used to identify which recovery points will be retained and for how long. This parameter works with the -WeeklyRetention, -MonthlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat, and -YearlyRetentionInWeeklyFormat options.

NOTE: You need to ensure that the days of the week that are picked for backup and for retention are aligned! For example, if backup is set for Saturdays then the weekly/monthly/yearly retention policies also must use Saturday as the -DaysOfWeek option.
Switch parameter that creates an object with Monthly retention information.

The days of the month used to identify which recovery points will be retained and for how long. This parameter works with the -DailyRetention, -MonthlyRetentionInDailyFormat, and -YearlyRetentionInDailyFormat options.
Switch parameter that creates an object with Monthly retention information.
When defining monthly retention, this parameter specifies which week of the month has the recovery points that should get monthly retention.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Azure Backup vault based on the parameters that are specified. A vault is the start point for all backup operations with Azure Backup.

The New-AzureRMBackupVault commandlet creates and Azure Backup vault and returns an object of type AzurePSBackupVault that acts as a reference to the vault entity. The vault has some important properties that define the scope of backup – the region and the storage type.

Specifies the name of an existing resource group. In order to create a resource group, use the New-AzureResourceGroup commandlet. There is no requirement that the Azure ResourceGroup and the Azure Backup vault be in the same region.

Specifies the name of the Azure Backup vault. The combination of ResourceGroupName and Name must be unique. You cannot create two vaults with the same name under the same ResourceGroup, but two vaults with the same name can be placed under two different Resource Groups.

The region parameter places the vault object into a specific Azure region. For hybrid backup scenarios, it is advised to create a vault in a region close to the on-premise server to reduce latency. For backup of Azure IaaS virtual machines, the vault becomes the point of discovery for local virtual machines.

Backup storage is billed at Azure Storage rates and users can choose between LocallyRedundant and GeoRedundant as the storage for the backup data. Since this is an optional parameter, if it is not specified then the vault is created with the GeoRedundant Storage option.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object

Specifies the name of an existing resource group. In order to create a resource group, use the New-AzureResourceGroup commandlet. There is no requirement that the Azure ResourceGroup and the Azure Backup vault be in the same region.

Specifies the name of the Azure Backup vault. The combination of ResourceGroupName and Name must be unique. You cannot create two vaults with the same name under the same ResourceGroup, but two vaults with the same name can be placed under two different Resource Groups.

The region parameter places the vault object into a specific Azure region. For hybrid backup scenarios, it is advised to create a vault in a region close to the on-premise server to reduce latency. For backup of Azure IaaS virtual machines, the vault becomes the point of discovery for local virtual machines.

Backup storage is billed at Azure Storage rates and users can choose between LocallyRedundant and GeoRedundant as the storage for the backup data. Since this is an optional parameter, if it is not specified then the vault is created with the GeoRedundant Storage option.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

maml:description.maml:para: Register the container with the Azure Backup vault

The first step towards configuring backup with Azure Backup is to register your machine or VM with an Azure Backup vault. This commandlet takes the input information of an Azure IaaS virtual machine and registers it with the specified vault. The register operation associates the Azure virtual machine with the backup vault and tracks the VM through the backup lifecycle.
Name of the Azure VM to be registered.

The cloud service name of the Azure VM to be registered. Typically the cloud service name has a suffix ".cloudapp.net". Do not include the suffix as input to this commandlet! You can use the Get-AzureVM commandlet (in the AzureServiceManagement mode) to get the VM information; the service name is the DeploymentName property in the VM object.
The Azure Backup vault to which the Azure VM should be registered.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Name of the Azure VM to be registered.
If your VM is created in the AzureResourceManager mode, then instead of -ServiceName you will need to use this parameter
The Azure Backup vault to which the Azure VM should be registered.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Name of the Azure VM to be registered.

The cloud service name of the Azure VM to be registered. Typically the cloud service name has a suffix ".cloudapp.net". Do not include the suffix as input to this commandlet! You can use the Get-AzureVM commandlet (in the AzureServiceManagement mode) to get the VM information; the service name is the DeploymentName property in the VM object.
The Azure Backup vault to which the Azure VM should be registered.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
If your VM is created in the AzureResourceManager mode, then instead of -ServiceName you will need to use this parameter
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Register a virtual machine to an Azure Backup vault --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: None

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a backup policy from the vault
Deletes the specified policy from the backup vault.
The protection policy object that has information about the policy. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet to get a list of protection policy objects.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The protection policy object that has information about the policy. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy commandlet to get a list of protection policy objects.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

maml:alert.maml:para: The policy must not have any associated Items that are protected. If you need to delete the policy, ensure that each associated item is protected with some other policy first. To associate another policy with a backup item, use the Enable-AzureRMBackupProtection commandlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: In this example, we fetch a policy named "DailyBackup" and pipe the policy object to the Remove commandlet.
None

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the Azure Backup vault object based on the parameters that are specified.

The Remove-AzureBackupVault commandlet deletes the backup vault. However, before a vault can be removed, it must first be empty – it must contain no backup data or protected items or registered servers. This ensures that a vault cannot be deleted inadvertently; the deletion of a backup vault is a planned operation.
Use the Remove-AzureBackupContainer commandlet to clear up IaaS VM backup data from the vault, or use the Delete-RegisteredServer commandlet to clear up other registered servers and backup data.
The specific Azure Backup vault object which needs to be removed. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The specific Azure Backup vault object which needs to be removed. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
Restores the data and config for a point in time

In order to restore backup data, you need to identify the backed-up item and the recovery point that holds the point-in-time data that needs to be restored. This information is supplied to the Restore-AzureRMBackupItem commandlet to initiate a restore of data from the vault to the customer's account.
The target storage account name in the customer subscription. As a part of the restore process, the disks and the config information will be placed in this storage account.
The recovery point object that has information about which specific point-in-time needs to be restored.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The target storage account name in the customer subscription. As a part of the restore process, the disks and the config information will be placed in this storage account.
The recovery point object that has information about which specific point-in-time needs to be restored.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

maml:alert.maml:para: Triggering a restore operation in PowerShell does not restore the full VM. It restores only the disk data and config information. The user has to additionally create the VM and start it after the restore operation has completed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Restore a recovery point --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $rp = Get-AzureRMBackupContainer -Type AzureVM -Status Registered -Vault $v | Get-AzureRMBackupItem | Get-AzureRMBackupRecoveryPoint PS C:\> Restore-AzureRMBackupItem -StorageAccountName "destaccount" -RecoveryPoint $rp

dev:remarks.maml:para: WorkloadName Operation Status StartTime EndTime ------------ --------- ------ --------- ------- test-vm Restore InProgress 26-Aug-15 1:14:01 PM 01-Jan-01 12:00:00 AM

maml:description.maml:para: Update an existing protection policy
The protection policy has multiple components: - Name - Backup schedule - Retention policies
This commandlet allows you to update one or more of the components of the policy. The change might affect the backup and retention of the items associated with the policy.
An optional parameter that specifies the new name for the policy. As with any policy, this value should be unique within a vault
An optional parameter that specifies the new backup time for the policy.
An optional parameter that specifies one or more new retention policies to be associated with the protection policy.
The protection policy object that refers to the original policy that this commandlet will update.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
An optional parameter that specifies the new name for the policy. As with any policy, this value should be unique within a vault
An optional parameter that sets the backup operation to run at a Daily schedule. Refer to New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy for examples.
An optional parameter that specifies the new backup time for the policy.
An optional parameter that specifies one or more new retention policies to be associated with the protection policy.
The protection policy object that refers to the original policy that this commandlet will update.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
An optional parameter that specifies the new name for the policy. As with any policy, this value should be unique within a vault
An optional parameter that sets the backup operation to run at a Weekly schedule. Refer to New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy for examples.
An optional parameter that specifies the new backup time for the policy.
An optional parameter that specifies one or more new retention policies to be associated with the protection policy.
An optional parameter that sets the backup operation to run on specific days of the week. Used in conjunction with the -Weekly parameter. Refer to New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy for examples.
The protection policy object that refers to the original policy that this commandlet will update.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
An optional parameter that specifies the new name for the policy. As with any policy, this value should be unique within a vault
An optional parameter that specifies the new backup time for the policy.
An optional parameter that specifies one or more new retention policies to be associated with the protection policy.
The protection policy object that refers to the original policy that this commandlet will update.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
An optional parameter that sets the backup operation to run at a Daily schedule. Refer to New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy for examples.
An optional parameter that sets the backup operation to run at a Weekly schedule. Refer to New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy for examples.
An optional parameter that sets the backup operation to run on specific days of the week. Used in conjunction with the -Weekly parameter. Refer to New-AzureRMBackupProtectionPolicy for examples.
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.
Changes the properties of the Azure Backup vault object based on the parameters that are specified.
The Set-AzureBackupVault commandlet allows you to change the storage type of the backup vault. The other parameters like Region, Name, and ResourceGroupName are not editable.
Users can choose between LocallyRedundant and GeoRedundant as the storage for the backup data.
The specific Azure Backup vault object for which the properties need to be updated. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Users can choose between LocallyRedundant and GeoRedundant as the storage for the backup data.
The specific Azure Backup vault object for which the properties need to be updated. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

maml:alert.maml:para: The storage type is locked on the registration of the first server or virtual machine, and cannot be changed afterwards.

maml:description.maml:para: Cancels an ongoing Azure Backup job
This commandlet cancels an existing Azure Backup job. This is particularly helpful if the job is taking too long and is blocking other activities.
The types of jobs that can be stopped are: - Backup - Restore
All other job types are not cancellable.
Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.

The GUID that uniquely identifies a job in the Azure Backup service. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet to get one or more jobs. From the AzureRMBackupJob object, use the InstanceId field for this value.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The job object that contains information about the job. The commandlet will attempt to stop (or cancel) this job.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
Use the Get-AzureRMBackupVault to get a list of vaults.

The GUID that uniquely identifies a job in the Azure Backup service. Use the Get-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet to get one or more jobs. From the AzureRMBackupJob object, use the InstanceId field for this value.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The job object that contains information about the job. The commandlet will attempt to stop (or cancel) this job.
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: In this example, the AzureRMBackupJob objects returned by the Get-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet are piped to the Stop-AzureRMBackupJob commandlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Unregisters the specified Windows Server or Azure virtual machine from the Azure Backup vault.

The Unregister command works on an Container object. It removes references of this container from the Azure Backup vault. Before you can Unregister a Container, any protected data associated with the Container needs to be deleted.
When applied to an AzureBackupContainer of type Windows, this will not prompt the user for explicit consent before deleting data from the Azure Backup vault.
The Windows Server or Azure virtual machine that should be unregistered.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
When applied to an AzureBackupContainer of type Windows, this will not prompt the user for explicit consent before deleting data from the Azure Backup vault.
The Windows Server or Azure virtual machine that should be unregistered.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

dev:type.maml:name: AzureBackupJob - For containers of type Windows Server, the return value is $null

maml:description.maml:para: This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Unregister a Windows Server with user prompt --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: The user first gets the container that needs to be unregistered using the Get-AzureBackupContainer commandlet. This container object is passed to the unregister commandlet. This unregisters the specified Windows Server from the Azure Backup vault.

Unregister Server This operation will delete all data in the backup vault that is associated with the server. Are you sure you want to unregister the server? [] Yes [] No [?] Help (default is "No"): Yes

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Unregister a Windows Server without confirmation prompt --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: The -Force option does not ask the user for confirmation before deleting the data and unregistering the server.
None

maml:description.maml:para: Waits for an Azure Backup job to complete

Long running operations are tracked in the Azure Backup service using jobs. To script out a workflow sequence that involves such a long running operations, the script has to wait for the operation to finish before starting the next one. This commandlet allows the script to pause until the job completes.
Scripting with this commandlet makes the script code simpler with no need to "poll" for the job status.
The job object that contains information about the job. The commandlet will wait for this job to complete.

The maximum time (in seconds) that the commandlet should wait for the job to complete. It is advised that a timeout value should always be specified to prevent infinite waiting. In order to wait 24 hours, set the timeout value to 86400.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
The job object that contains information about the job. The commandlet will wait for this job to complete.

The maximum time (in seconds) that the commandlet should wait for the job to complete. It is advised that a timeout value should always be specified to prevent infinite waiting. In order to wait 24 hours, set the timeout value to 86400.
Non-mandatory AzureProfile input object
This section details out the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

dev:type.maml:name: AzureRMBackupJob object (or) Array of AzureRMBackupJob objects

maml:description.maml:para: This section details out the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.
